headline.main: Cambridge, Mass., Equalizes Cost of Health Insurance for Gay Workers

docs.abstract: While an increasing number of companies are equalize the cost of health coverage for gay families, the city of Cambridge, Mass., is the first municipality to adopt the policy.
docs.snippet: While an increasing number of companies are equalize the cost of health coverage for gay families, the city of Cambridge, Mass., is the first municipality to adopt the policy.

docs.lead_paragraph: The city of Cambridge, Mass., may be the first municipality to equalize the cost of health benefits for its gay employees, following the lead of many corporations.

docs.lead_paragraph: The conversation continues in response to Dr. Karen Sibert’s op-ed piece wondering whether women should be doctors if they also want flexibility in their working lives.
When Representative Gerald E. Connolly, Democrat of Virginia, tried to send a taxpayer-paid newsletter to his constituents this month, the Republican majority had a few edits first.
docs.abstract: Democrats in the House are objecting to Republican censorship of Congressional newsletters.
docs.snippet: Democrats in the House are objecting to Republican censorship of Congressional newsletters.

docs.lead_paragraph: As more states turn to health plans to deliver Medicaid services, a Commonwealth Fund report published on Wednesday analyzes the cost and quality among plans with publicly traded stock.
docs.abstract: Many companies with publicly traded stock are expected to capitalize on the growth of Medicaid plans.
docs.snippet: Many companies with publicly traded stock are expected to capitalize on the growth of Medicaid plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”
docs.abstract: Swaying regulators against tighter capital standards may not prove easy for the banking industry, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Swaying regulators against tighter capital standards may not prove easy for the banking industry, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Rick Perlstein sends me to Sam Husseini asking Paul Ryan why, if he’s so concerned with government spending on health care, he doesn’t support single-payer. Ryan’s response is pure gobbledygook: he never answers the question, cites irrelevant facts (Medicare costs are rising! But what about private insurance, which is rising even faster?), and in general stonewalls and runs out the clock.
docs.abstract: More on the very unserious Paul Ryan.
docs.snippet: More on the very unserious Paul Ryan.

docs.lead_paragraph: NASA is planning to spend about half a billion dollars next year to replenish the pension fund of United Space Alliance, which supplies workers to the space shuttle program.
